<target_code>
Here is the code of get_rq_unames_size:
```c
_MHD_static_inline size_t
get_rq_unames_size (const struct MHD_RqDAuth *params,
                    enum MHD_DigestAuthUsernameType uname_type)
{
  size_t s;

  mhd_assert (get_rq_uname_type (params) == uname_type);
  s = 0;
  if ((MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_UNAME_TYPE_STANDARD == uname_type) ||
      (MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_UNAME_TYPE_USERHASH == uname_type) )
  {
    s += params->username.value.len + 1; /* Add one byte for zero-termination */
    if (MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_UNAME_TYPE_USERHASH == uname_type)
      s += (params->username.value.len + 1) / 2;
  }
  else if (MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_UNAME_TYPE_EXTENDED == uname_type)
    s += params->username_ext.value.len
         - MHD_DAUTH_EXT_PARAM_MIN_LEN + 1; /* Add one byte for zero-termination */
  return s;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Only explicit function calls in this fragment can introduce direct or indirect recursion. The line mhd_assert(get_rq_uname_type(params) == uname_type) and the nested call get_rq_uname_type(params) are the only calls to other functions/macros in this function; get_rq_uname_type must be inspected to ensure it does not (directly or indirectly) call get_rq_unames_size. The other code (constant comparisons with MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_UNAME_TYPE_*, arithmetic on s, struct field accesses like params->username.value.len and params->username_ext.value.len, the return statement, and the inline/storage specifier) contain no function calls and therefore cannot create recursion and do not need further investigation for Rule 17.2.
